risks.title: Computational Resource Management for Local AI Models
risks.description: Local AI models, especially multimodal ones like Qwen2.5-VL, are highly resource-intensive, requiring significant VRAM and system RAM. This could limit the target audience to users with high-end hardware or dedicated servers, potentially excluding a broader market, especially for mobile integration.

evidence.quote: The 7B/8B Qwen2.5-VL models require approximately 24GB VRAM and 32GB system RAM. The 32B version would need a Mac M-series with at least 32GB RAM (64GB recommended) and over 60GB of storage. These are significant hardware considerations for local deployment.

mitigation: Optimize models for efficiency, including quantization and efficient inference techniques where possible.
Implement intelligent task scheduling to run resource-heavy processes during user inactivity or when resources are abundant.
Offer clear hardware specifications and guides for cost-effective setups.
Provide optional paid cloud-based AI processing for users lacking sufficient local hardware.

risks.title: Mobile Data Collection Limitations
risks.description: Full, continuous background screen monitoring and detailed UI event capture, as envisioned for desktops, are highly challenging and likely infeasible on non-jailbroken iOS and Android devices due to strict OS-level restrictions. This limits PrivateAI's ability to offer a truly seamless 'second brain' experience across mobile platforms.

evidence.quote: Full, continuous background screen monitoring and detailed UI event capture (as envisioned for desktops) are highly challenging and likely infeasible on non-jailbroken iOS and Android devices due to strict OS-level restrictions on background activity and data access.
The mobile client's role may need to shift from pervasive monitoring to more active, user-driven input.

mitigation: Adapt mobile strategy to focus on user-initiated actions and OS-compliant integrations (e.g., Share Button, notification capture, Foreground App Capture).
Utilize device's native AI capabilities for on-device processing where app can legitimately access data.
Clearly communicate mobile limitations and align user expectations with feasible mobile functionalities.
Exclude comprehensive mobile app support beyond basic input from the initial MVP to manage scope.

risks.title: Competition from Rapidly Evolving AI Landscape & Big Tech
risks.description: The AI landscape is rapidly evolving, and major tech companies with vast resources could release similar features, potentially eroding PrivateAI's competitive edge. While PrivateAI focuses on privacy, big tech could also improve their on-device offerings.

evidence.quote: Rapidly Evolving AI Landscape & Big Tech Competition: Major tech companies could release similar features. This is a significant concern.
Sustainability of 'Local-First' Advantage: OS vendors might improve on-device privacy features.

mitigation: Focus relentlessly on absolute privacy, deep data integration, open extensibility, and community to differentiate.
Maintain agility in development to quickly adapt to market changes and new AI advancements.
Build a strong brand around data sovereignty and user empowerment, cultivating a loyal user base.
Explore partnerships with entities sharing anti-big-tech sentiments, such as privacy-focused companies.

risks.title: Plugin System Security Risks
risks.description: The initial idea of downloading Rust source code, compiling it locally, and running the resulting binary for plugins poses major security risks and usability hurdles. An insecure plugin system could compromise user data or system integrity, undermining the core privacy promise.

evidence.quote: Initial (High-Risk) Idea for Rust Plugins: Download Rust source code, compile it locally on the user's machine, and then run the resulting binary. The core application would manage these processes. Research documents strongly advise against this due to major security risks and usability hurdles.
The system must be exceptionally clear and transparent about what data is being collected, from which sources, how frequently, and how this data is being processed and utilized by the AI components.

mitigation: Strongly adopt WebAssembly (WASM) for sandboxed execution of all plugins, ensuring a secure and controlled environment.
Implement robust plugin manifests that define capabilities, data dependencies, resource requirements, and explicitly requested permissions, enforced by the Core application.
Establish a clear distinction between audited (trusted) and unaudited (third-party) plugins with appropriate warnings and user consent mechanisms.
Invest in rigorous security audits and community-driven vulnerability identification programs.

risks.title: Founder's Desire to Avoid Management Responsibilities
risks.description: The founder, Bartosz (CTO), prefers to focus on R&D and avoid extensive people management, indicating a need for a replacement CTO or a strong People Manager/Team Lead. This could create a leadership gap or divert resources if not addressed proactively during growth phases.

evidence.quote: Bartosz (CTO) Role: Primary focus on R&D, developing new ideas and products. Prefers to avoid extensive people management associated with a CTO role in a larger company and is open to finding a replacement CTO after achieving a higher valuation because he wants to focus on R&D, not management.
People Manager / Team Lead: Required because the founder wishes to focus on technology rather than direct people management.

mitigation: Prioritize hiring a skilled People Manager / Team Lead early in the project to manage day-to-day team operations.
Develop a clear succession plan for the CTO role, potentially identifying and mentoring an internal candidate or actively recruiting an external CTO.
Ensure the founding team is aware of and aligned with this dynamic, allowing Bartosz to focus on his core strengths in R&D.
Utilize a strong Employee Stock Option Plan (ESOP) to attract high-caliber leadership talent.
